paper_abstract: By refining a variant of the Klee-Minty example that forces the central path to visit all the vertices of the Klee-Minty n-cube, we exhibit a nearly worst-case example for path-following interior point methods. Namely, while the theoretical iteration-complexity upper bound is O(2(n) n(5/2)), we prove that solving this n-dimensional linear optimization problem requires at least 2(n)-1 iterations.
paper_title: How good are interior point methods? Klee-Minty cubes tighten iteration-complexity bounds
